reviews.title: Sill going strong at 178000
reviews.review_text: I bought one five years ago for $3500, when it had 115000 miles. It was a rush purchase, but not a bad one. When I bought an Infiniti G35S last year, a second-car discount on my insurance swayed me to keep this one instead of selling it. Over the past few years I've replaced the distributor cap, timing belt, and muffler, and fixed the clutch -- all things that fall under maintenance, so I can't complain. Now I have a great second car that helps keep the mileage off the Infiniti, or a loaner when a friend's car is in the shop. It was worth the repairs because at almost 180000 miles it's still a smooth ride. Given the longevity of Honda engines, I suspect I'll probably hold onto it a while longer. I only wouldn't recommend this outright because it's an old car, but if you need a basic, reliable ride for low $$$ you can't go wrong with this one.

reviews.title: My First Sports Car
reviews.review_text: This is my second car and my first sports car. I'm not big on the style of the head lights and tail lights, but in general I think it looks good. The acceleration is pretty good, but what blows me away is the handling and fuel economy. I drive a lot, so the great gas mileage really helps. I find the seats to be pretty comfortable. I haven't had to sit in the back seats, but they look alright. And of course, it's an Acura, so it will just keep going. You can get 300,000 miles out of it no problem. I bought it from a friend of mine and he took great care of it so I'm blessed with an amazing little car.

reviews.title: Car that has lasted 14 years now
reviews.review_text: Car is fantastic and just keeps on going. Not the most comfortable inside, but it makes up for itself in the sports car design, handling, and performance

reviews.title: well build, sporty, a little cramped.
reviews.review_text: I bought mine used just 2 months ago from a used car dealer for $7000CDN. It had 165,000KM on it. Both the exterior and interior were in good condition for the age of the car. There is a bit of rust in the back wheel-well, but I hear that is very common. The paint still shine, I assume it's the original paint. I drove it from Calgary to Vancouver-- and Back, that's about 2000KM. At $1.03/L, the whole trip costed about $120 for gas. Milage is pretty good. I don't have the V-Tec version, but acceleration is still good in the city. I am usually the first off at the lights. On the Hwy it got up to 190km/h when I floored it. It's a sporty ride, handles corners very well. Some of the dash lights flicker sometimes, but it's nothing critical.

reviews.title: 1994 Acura Integra
reviews.review_text: I owned the Integra for 11 years and I was very happy with my purchase.It was great on gas and reliable. I purchased the vehicle new in 1994. I was very happy with the performance and handling, it was fun to drive. I wished that the seats had been more comfortable but that's normal for most sports cars.

reviews.title: Cheap and reliable!
reviews.review_text: I bought this car to a friend for $1000 because I urgently needed a second car for my commutes. The car had 171,000 miles on it, the red paint was severely faded, a fender had rust, and the exhaust was vibrating loudly when the engine was cold. But other than the clutch that I replaced two weeks after I bought it, the car was a tank and never let me down. The a/c never gave up. The interior was outdated but still in perfect shape for the age of the car, and the trunk was surprisingly roomy. If you're on a very tight budget and if you're looking for an old car, good on gas, cheap to maintain, and if you can find one that has not been modified, go for it, no matter what the mileage is.

reviews.title: She's My bae
reviews.review_text: She's fast and easy to work on. What can I say? First, a tiny bit of backstory about myself, my first car was a '99 Honda Civic, which I rather loved. And I love this car WAY more. This car works well for me because it is little, and I am not a very large person. At the same time, bigger and taller people can fit in this thing because of how the seats are angled. I've seen it happen in my own ride. It's not too bad on gas at all, but considering it's designed to be a sports car, it probably guzzles gas a bit more than say... a Honda Civic. But yeah, she's classy in front, and sexy from behind. A true JDM classic. She has a pretty dang spacious hatchback-trunk, as well. Another couple reasons to consider an old Integra, is parts for this car are cheap and plentiful, especially on eBay. You can basically have an old car that runs almost like a new one for dirt cheap if you take advantage of that. I got her pretty tuned, and let me tell you, she is friggin' fast. And gonna get faster. Believe me, I've got plans for this car, flippin' sweet plans. And I've got mostly eBay to thank for that. And local parts stores as well, can't forget them. Even though this car has been discontinued, it is certainly not obsolete, trust me. The other reason is you can probably find one on Craigslist or Facebook marketplace used, for dirt cheap. reviews.title: Most reliable, fun car I've ever owned.
reviews.review_text: Let me start by saying that the only reason I gave it four stars in comfort is because of how cramped the back seat is. For the driver and front passenger, it's VERY comfortable! I had the 1993 Acura Integra GS Coupe, with a 5 speed manual. In regular driving, gas mileage was about 30-32 mpg. But, since it was a manual, I found that I could always cruse in a higher gear that was "necessary" in order to get even better mileage. I usually got about 320 miles to a (13 gallon) tank, but being stingy about the gearing and the way I drove, I got up to 360 some times. It may have the styling and fun of a coupe, but it is technically a hatchback, and comes with all the versatility and practicality of one. You can lay the seats down flat and have huge cargo space, but even if you don't, the trunk is a very good size for such a small car. You also get a rear window wiper, which is one thing I can't stand not having. Being the GS trim, mine came with very nice black leather seats, a power sunroof (far better than most, I might add), power windows and mirrors, and antilock brakes. Even though the antilock brakes is only offered on the GS, they all come with four wheel disks, which is very good, considering it's a 90's car. Another thing to mention is that THIS CAR IS FAST! Not like "European Supercar" fast, but fast. It will do 110 miles per hour in fourth gear. Imagine what it can do in fifth! It goes from 0-60 in about 7.5-8 seconds. I've never actually timed it, that's just my guess. It also has a nice exhaust note. It would sound better with a magnaflow, but for a stock four cylinder motor, it sounds very good! I LOVED that car, and would have kept it for a good long time. Unfortunately, I was side-swiped by a big SUV, and the car was beyond totaled. It's totally crash worthy, though. It was a pretty nasty crash, and I walked away with only minor bruises. I wish the same could be said for the car, though. Definitely a car worth buying, you will not regret it! It only lets me pick one primary use, so I put Just getting around, which is what I did the most. But if you're looking for a car to have fun with, the Integra will not disappoint!

reviews.title: Best car I've ever owned!
reviews.review_text: I've had my Integra since '96, and it's been fun, sporty and reliable. It's had it's share of problems over the years, but nothing out of the ordinary for an aging vehicle. I still wouldn't even think twice about jumping in and heading out for a long road trip. In the 11 years I've owned it, I had to tow it only once (and that was because my mechanic had screwed something up that morning). Great gas mileage. Excellent visibility all around. Surprising amount of cargo space. Still looks sharp after 14 years. Parts are easily available. Outstanding car. Complaints: Not many. Back seats are cramped (it's a small car, after all). Peppy, but could use a few more hp. Overall, I'm very happy and would buy one again! Tip: Avoid Integras that are all pimped-out, sellers with stock Integras are less likely to have abused them.

reviews.title: Most shocking car ever :)
reviews.review_text: I got a 91 KA7 (Sedan) Acura Legend L as a point A to B car in college. Considering that it had over 400K known miles on the motor before the odometer clocked out along with the speedometer even issues with the transmission it was a shockingly pleasant car. The original owner(s) never took care of it but this car was a beast. It kept on moving regardless of issues. My main issue as a college student was never having the money to properly fix it up, my area lacked a lot of these cars so parts were hard to find in the junkyard. The times for some sad reason another Legend KA7 sedan or KA8 coupe ended up in the junk yard most times parts were easy to take and use on my car I was using at the time. As a student I managed to replace parts on this car rather easily with research and restored it to its former "working glory". Can't get around transmission issue really or fix the speedometer without destroying the transmission so I used a Speed App on my phone to get around. It isn't a bad fix to actually fix the transmission but as a college student I made due with what I had. Poured some Lucas in there and made it work. These cars are a rarity. Actually found out they are rarer than BMWs, but then again it depends on the city. My college town has very few riding the streets. I never really noticed any others out there. Tallahassee FL on the other hand I saw some there every time I went out there for family. Even their junk yards had plenty of them there due to poor treatment. Admittedly I received the car with some cosmetic issues but for it's age and appearance it was still a head turner for anyone I pulled up to. For their time they actually had a ton of features way ahead of their time in the 90s. Minus the fact that there are no cup holders this is definitely a car of Luxury, Reliability, Comfort, and even Power. 4 Speed Autos can be driven as a clutchless manual with the gears (1, 2, D3, and D4). With 200 hp, a wider body and lower ride for cars in this category this car will get up and go. So long as one is willing to understand the age of this vehicle if anyone is able to find one in great working condition or knows how to fix cars rather well I'd highly recommend this vehicle as a Luxury, Family, or even a fun car. I miss the car everyday and I dislike sedans. Looking to maybe one day get a 95 KA8 (coupe) Legend LS 6 speed manual with the type two C32A5 3.2L V6 230hp motor. Honda placed a lot of thought into making this car. Though it is still made overseas the name for Acura has been changed over to "Acura TL". The Acura/Honda Legend are amazing cars as a sedan or a coupe. As a automatic or a manual they are made to run for the longevity of the owner so long as they are taken care of.

reviews.title: Exceptional Sport Hybrid and Yes It Is Sporty
reviews.review_text: The Acura MDX Advanced Sport Hybrid is an exceptional large SUV that is incredibly agile for its size. It is quite, well appointed, attractive and secure. Acceleration is brisk and stopping distance is quite good for a vehicle of this weight. Fuel mileage has been very strong and I have found that I can run on pure electric for longer than manufacturer claims. I have been able to go more that 50 miles on pure electric power at a speed of 35 miles an hour during a recent trip through a scenic byway. If you are looking for 6/7 seater that is a joy to drive the Acura MDX Advanced Sport Hybrid is a fantastic choice.

reviews.title: Very comfortable automobile.
reviews.review_text: The Acura has a great technology package that sets it apart from the competition. It is a very comfortable car that has some real get up and go!

reviews.review_text: It’s been a long time since we bought a car and we were definitely dreading the process. Andrew was outstanding and made us feel so comfortable. He ensured we had a great customer experience. We would definitely do business with the Curry Acura again. Thanks!

reviews.title: Very safe and reliable car
reviews.review_text: I love it. It’s my eighth one. It’s comfortable and reliable . It’s very roomy for a large family. I would certainly recommend this to anyone looking for an suv

reviews.title: Amazing Drive + Comfort
reviews.review_text: Plenty of cabin room and the 3rd row is a bonus to have. It might sound weird, but it's been a long time since I've been able to purchase items at BJs/Costco and then grocery shop in 1 trip. But the MDX allowed me to fit sooo much - it was great! The cabin is quite, comfortable, and pretty. The driving dynamic mode has 3 options: Comfort, Normal and Sport. The Sport mode is great - it tightens the steering wheel and really kicks up so the car doesn't feel so heavy (like when you can feel the engine working to drive such a heavy car). I could really go on and on about the MDX - but just go test drive it - you'll love it! And the new front exterior re-design (I believe it started with 2017) makes it look so intimidating and sexy!!!

reviews.title: Very nice mid size suv can’t go wrong with an MDX
reviews.review_text: We look at a lot of mid size SUVs . We chose the Acura MDX was the most comfortable, quietest out of all we drove. Plus it being an Acura for quality and the better than most warranty also helps in our decision.

reviews.title: 2nd generation I have owned
reviews.review_text: I fell in love with the MDXAspec color at first sight. I also once owned a previous MDX (2009) AND TL which I gave to my son when I decided to move on to the MDX. reviews.title: It is my 3rd MDX and a lot to say...
reviews.review_text: This is my 3rd MDX, and still a lot of things to be improved. I haven't put a lot of miles on it, so basically it is still a new car. Rattling noises inside the cabin never disappeared. The suspension is way below the average, and on Pennsylvania roads is a noise challenge. The technology inside the car is two generation behind if not more than that. Even the new 2021 model looks inside out of date with the old design infotainment that even Hyundai gave up quite some time ago. Same for the power plant and transmission, below average. For a car that wants to be a part of the luxury segment they need to do a lot of improvements on all those weak points.

reviews.title: 2019 Acura MDX-nice car, not the dealer experience
reviews.review_text: Bought it at a very good price, 3,700 miles. Very nice car. Rides well, lots of nice features. Drawback, but it is standard, is the lack of a full size spare tire. The real negative we have doesn't have to do with the car, but with the dealership. We weren't told it was missing one key fob, about $400 and a trip to an ACURA dealership a week later. A relatively inexpensive owner's manual was also missing. And, we discovered it was missing the floor mats. All three items were standard for a new ACURA, per ACURA. We were reimbursed by the dealership for the fob, but not for the floor mats. The car is fine. If I were EVER to consider another used car from this dealership, I would ask for a complete, and I mean COMPLETE, list of everything that comes standard with a new car, and a list of every item that the used car in question does not have. Summing up, very nice car (we've only had it 6 weeks, the caveat).

reviews.title: I have driven the MDX before and I am impressed
reviews.review_text: MDX has met all my expectations being reliable and can depend on every destinations where you are going. With extra seats we can always accommodate big families.

reviews.title: Nice SUV
reviews.review_text: The Acura MDX base model is a nice SUV. It has decent features for a base package. I feel that for the price you're paying, you should get more. It drives smooth and thats about it. The dash screen is not user friendly and at times difficult to operate. 3rd row USB/charger ports are behind the seats and you would have to take off your seat belt to access them (not ideal). Blind spot detection/parking sensors are not standard in the base model, which for a "luxury" vehicle should come standard in my opinion instead of having to pay up to $6k more to get those features in a Tech package. Long review short, I traded in my basic 2019 MDX for a 2020 Kia Telluride EX and couldn't be happier. I wanted more from the Acura and thought even the base model would have a lot of great features but it didn't. If you like Acuras and like a lot of tech features, don't get the base unless you have the extra cash to get into a Tech or A-spec model, which are really nice.

reviews.review_text: this is my second mdx in 17 years... i loved my first 2002 mdx but had a constant transmission issues(torque converter) that made the rpms jump in third ggear... After the second transmission rebuild I decided it was time to move on in 2008... Jump to 2017 and i get nostalgic and buy a 2014 mdx, thinking that those issues would have been resolved.. Nope, same torque converter issues, should have done more forum research... The current mdx i have is average at best.. the handling sucks, the acceleration is average, the gas milage is above average. What really eats me up with the acura dealership philosophy is their outrageous price for any service(stuff that would not be so crazy at other dealerships)... the roof rails and crossbars do not come standard but a dealship install(really) and the price is $900(xxx). My next car will not be an acura.

reviews.title: Very comfortable and excellent value
reviews.review_text: This car has every programmable feature that could possibly be desired. It is amazingly comfortable and has the quiet cabin that was primary for me.

reviews.title: It is overpriced
reviews.review_text: I love the look of the car!! It feels good to sit in. It has nice pickup while driving in the sport mode. Has a lot of features...too many, maybe. I do NOT like keyless cars, but that is my preference and nothing to do with Acura. Specific to the MDX, the doors are light weight and tinny feeling. The lumbar in my seat rolls around while I drive, there is a grasshopper hum sound on my roof when I am on the freeway. This is a brand new car, I've had it for 3 months. My door sensor was replaced at 1 week. The car quality feels low end, the price tag is not. Outside of the manufacturing short comings, this vehicle is ALL buttons. Push a button to start the car, push a button to drive reverse and park, push a button to operate climate control, radio, and all car settings. It is very distracting if you are driving because you MUST look at the screen in order to navigate these features. I've found this to be a negative about the car as I would prefer a dial or physical something to push rather than a touch screen button.

reviews.title: I will only drive an Acura MDX.
reviews.review_text: I was in a head-on collision in my 2017 MDX and lived to walk out of the hospital. My vehicle was totaled as was the other person’s car who crossed the th double solid center line passing another vehicle. This is the only car I want! My auto brake assist, airbags, and seatbelt did what they were supposed to do.

reviews.title: Great Vehicle with Excellent Value for the Money!
reviews.review_text: I've owned the vehicle for 2 months and it is great. Performance and styling are great and I haven't had anything needing repair so great initial quality (time will tell in regards to long term reliability). Android Auto/Apple Car Play, refined 9 speed and active dampers really make it a joy to drive. Any previous issues/complaints with the ZF9 speed transmission really appear to have been ironed out in my 2019. Only main gripe so far is the driver foot rest / dead pedal is a bit too close, too wide, and at too steep an angle for comfort. I'm 6' and it bothers me. More of a nuisance then a real problem but definitely wish I had an extra inch or 2 of legroom for my left leg. Another complaint (minor) is that the Adaptive Cruise Control works but is touchy. While it works well and brings the vehicle to a complete stop in stop and go traffic as advertised, acceleration can be somewhat aggressive/rough at times but overall it works great. Just wish it were a little less agressive with the throttle so it was more smooth. Compared with the Q7 and QX60 and glad I decided on the MDX. The Q7 would have been a great vehicle but ultimately I was concerned about long term reliability, cost of maintenance/parts, and the added cost in terms of purchase price and subscription fees to fully use the virtual cockpit/headsup display with navigation/route guidance. In terms of available features and value for the money it's really hard to beat the MDX.

reviews.title: Nicest car I've ever owned

So this review should be from the day after thanksgiving, not today, I had spent most of my Thanksgiving looking at replacement vehicles (I just had 2 massive spinal surgeries in the last 12 months, one from 12/18/19 and one from 10/11/20, I had been an Acura owner over and over for 14 years, I bought 6 Acura's total, 2 TLX's and 4 MDX's, I love the cars, I switched in 2019 to Toyota, this place has earned my respect and my business. The salesman........... normally id happily watch seal team 6 waterboard and torture the rep just to get a fair price, but Adrian just wanted a fair deal all around and to make a sale, I could have happily driven every car on the lot and he would have kept going, very polite/eager/ambitious young man. As a seasoned sales rep myself of 25 years I spotted the potential in Adrian very quickly, he uses the Sandler method in most cases, but he listens and if he doesn't know he doesn't try to BS hi way through it, he goes and gets a legit answer. Getting older and having major medical issues I purchased the prepaid maintenance and got the certified pre-owned which extends the warranty out, while the warranties are not worth it to some, ive come to learn over time with inflation that the tie rod that. reviews.title: Very good... but not Great
reviews.review_text: The current 2018 MDX is a very good and popular crossover. And in typical Acura form... they've managed to produce a vehicle that has versatility and value. One that has three rows for expanded carpooling, but is a bit smaller than many competitors; one that has a bevy of tech and safety features; and one that is incredibly smooth. For me, a single guy about to turn 30, I made the switch from the TLX sedan to this over 4,000-pound beast for a few reasons (none of which include needing room for 7 haha). But in making that switch, I knew things were going to feel different in terms of driving dynamics. And overall though, I can say it's been fairly seamless and that the MDX was a very familiar feel... highly typical when sticking with the same brand. And while on occasion it feels a tad big (like when parallel parking or weaving through the tight side-streets of a southern New England milltown), overall, I can easily say it drives smaller than it is... which is definitely a plus. Having a wider, more athletic stance its sister Honda Pilot helps it feel very planted in corners and not very top-heavy. The front seats are some of the most comfortable I've ever sat in (and as a car enthusiast, I've been in a lot of different cars). The Tech Package upgrades the sound system, which is absolutely fantastic and highly recommended for audiophiles like myself. Additionally, the Tech Package gives you Navigation, a slew of safety features, and remote start. And I can honestly say, even though it's only been in one snow storm so far, this car may as well be a plow. It's excellent! You actually work hard to get it out of shape, which tells me the traction control, SH-AWD, etc. are all doing their job. Unfortunately though, it's still lacking in some areas, the biggest being the power and drivetrain. I'm sorry Honda, but the ZF-9-speed transmission is garbage! After all the issues that Chrysler has had with it in their vehicles, I see Honda's implementation of it in their vehicles, in a luxury line no less, as an abysmal failure. It's wonky from a dead stop: if you baby it, you go no where... but if you give it any gas, it surges you forward like a rocket (but not in a good way). Believe me, I love a car that can get-up-and-go... but if ever I find a car I like has a ZF 9-Speed Automatic in it again, I'll cross it off my list and keep on looking... I don't care how much I like it. The V6 has a good, throaty sound (as throaty as you can get from a luxury crossover) and it provides decent but underwhelming power, something I attribute to the transmission too. Unlike the potent direct-injection 4-Cylinder I had in the TLX with the 8-Speed Dual-Clutch Transmission (a match made in heaven, IMO), the big single-overhead-cam V6 just doesn't deliver with the low-end torque, particularly at highway speeds. Yes, it's the "corporate V6", but it's aging... quickly! If I need to pass someone, I find I have to downshift at least two gears just to get going again. A larger turbo would probably be awesome in an MDX (like the 300+ HP 2.3L EcoBoost found in the Ford Mustang). Mate something like that with a better transmission (maybe the 7-speed dual-clutch found in the Sport Hybrid model?) and I think the results would be fantastic! Another part of the car I'm not thrilled with are the brakes. They are strong and quite smooth, but man, they creek incessantly. Every time I'm stopped, when I release the pedal to accelerate, I hear a creek from the brake caliber releasing. For a $50K luxury crossover this is unacceptable, and sadly, it's something Acura has had issues with in their SH-AWD vehicles going back to the 2012 TL! There is also (at least in my 2018) a squeal when hopping on and off the brakes, mostly when reversing (i.e.: when backing into a spot, etc.). I've had two dealers look at the problem... one couldn't figure it out so I received the "it's normal for the car" answer, and the other dealer thought they figured it out but I've heard it since. Not as often, but I've heard it. My concluding thoughts? For the money, the MDX is a really good buy and it IS a really good car. Would I lease another though? Well, it highly depends on what the alleged 2020 redesign brings to the table, because there is room for improvement. One can only hope the redesigned MDX gains more athleticism and power that mimics its smaller sibling, the RDX, while maintaining the smoothness and comfort MDX buyers love.

reviews.title: Excellent SUV
reviews.review_text: This is my 5th MDX and although all of them have been great, each one is better than the previous one. I have looked carefully and extensively at many other SUV's (including Audi, BMW, Ford, Infinity, Lexus, Lincoln, Toyota and Volvo) prior to getting each of the MDX'S and Acura continuously does a great job of providing a variety of amenities that the others either don't provide or not nearly to the same extent. These include spacious storage in the console area with easy access, an arm rest that slides forward/backward, a large hidden storage bin behind the 3rd seat and a compass with the street name currently being driven on, indicated at the top middle section of the gauge display (with GPS navigation information, while it;s being used, also provided in this area as well as on the center navigation screen). Also, the blind spot warning indicator is inside the vehicle near the front bottom corner of each of the front windows as opposed to where it is located in so many other vehicles where it is commonly within the side view mirrors which is not always easy to see when it's raining or there is ice or water on the mirror or even when the window needs to be defogged or defrosted. There many other features included in the MDX that are each well thought out by Acura. The MDX is very spacious and roomy and yet the vehicle has a relatively low profile when compared to so many of the other SUV's that are comparable in size. Bottom line: if you are looking for an SUV, make sure you take a good look at the Acura MDX. It is comfortable, dependable, enjoyable to drive, has excellent fit and finish, is loaded with features and is a great value.

reviews.title: Real Value In Mid-Sized Luxury SUV
reviews.review_text: No, it's not a Q7 or a QX60 but that's a good thing. Dollar-for-dollar and feature-for-feature, this SUV is by far the leader of the pack. I purchased an MDX Advent (Advance with Entertainment Package) for $25k (several thousand below the competition) ... and from an Audi dealer! Ride, comfort and performance are top shelf. The nine-speed transmission can be a bit much on takeoff, but shifts nicely, unlike others I've driven. This model has all the safety features, including the birds-eye camera, lacking on many competitors. The power folding mirrors come in handy in the garage and at the car wash. The dual screens require a bit of getting used to, but once mastered are a great feature, especially with the navigation at eye level. On top of all that, it's a good-looking vehicle, especially since Acura replaced that "smiley-face" grill (it was my primary reason for avoiding so much as test-driving one). This one's a keeper!

reviews.title: Average SUV don't expect to be impressed
reviews.review_text: Had multiple ACURA' s over the duration of owning vehicles with overall positive experience. When I needed an SUV to pull a small enclosed motorcycle trailer I looked at the MDX technology package. With the 3500 pound towing capacity it pulled the 2000 pound trailer with Harley Davidson but labored at times. The vehicle overall is made of thin metal, small stones would dent the front, top was dented by heavy rain storm. Paint job was poor and lacked finish, interior is low quality leather and plastic, very uncomfortable front seating for long distance drives, infotainment is poorly designed and not intuitive, GPS is horrible 1980's technology, steering wheel frequently failed to return to designation position (service department could not resolve), NO base from stereo system, adaptive cruise control does not work, false positives for collision control and applied brakes when not required. When driving the vehicle without trailer it is responsive, headlights are bright at night but automatic bright lights failed and had to be applied manually, lane control works well as long as it is not raining. Overall the vehicle was disappointing for the cost.

reviews.title: Great car so far.
reviews.review_text: Purchased the car in October of 2017 and so far it's been a great ride. I traded in a domestic/US built, so called luxury version that was nothing but problems. SYNC-2 earns it's name of STINK as the vehicle was a nightmare from day 1. I was able to take advantage of year end pricing to make the switch. The car has a very similar feel to the last generation BMW X5's I drove from 2003 up to the 2013. My 1st 2003 X5 had a V8 with ~290 HP, was fairly loaded up and cost in the mid $50K range. The 2017 MDX has ~290HP, cost in low to mid $50's depending on the options and seems to ride better. The MDX has the same thick steering wheel, steering wheel controls seat controls/angle it can be set to all have a familiar feel to them as they are similar to the X5. The phone interface seems a bit quirky (2018 has Applecar play) however most of these things just take time and a learning curve. The fuel economy is something I am already really impressed with. Getting in the low 20's in city driving and high 20's on the highway. The car rides extremely nice! It was the first thing I and several family members noticed when they have been in it for a drive. I purchased the vehicle based on the advice of 2 different doctors who can drive anything they want and they both said these cars are really worth a look and are a great value. About the only thing I am still not totally fond of yet is the front grill, an all mesh with smaller logo or something less garish would be the feedback. If the mileage, reliability and comfort remain at the high level I have had so far, then I don't think I will care what the grill looks like as my ownership experience goes on.

reviews.title: This is my second MDX
reviews.review_text: I had a 2004 and loved it. Decided to move into a new one. The `17 MDX is very comfortable. The 9 speed trans is a bit much, but I like that it holds a gear when driving down hill. I have found that it doesn?t downshift very fast if you want to pass a car in D mode. If I switch to S (sport) mode it works great. This car has a lot of technology in it and some of it is not intuitive. That just means I have to read the owners manual and learn how it works. I see a lot of people complain that this or that doesn?t work. In my experience as a master mechanic, I find that the owner simply has not learned how to use a feature, or it does not work like they think it should. I have had a problem with the voice activation feature. You can do almost anything from changing radio stations, putting in a address to changing the air temp. I just need to work with it some more. The one thing I do not like is the 20 inch wheels. It makes for a more rough ride. A 17 inch wheel with a non run flat tire has a much more comfortable ride and takes the bumps better. The active cruise takes some getting used to. This SUV is the only one I could find that you can turn off the radar and have a regular cruise control. I have only had it for a couple of weeks so I will update my review after I have driven in the snow and off road.

reviews.title: The last vehicle I buy??
reviews.review_text: Wanted comfort, reliability, intuitive technology and sporty drive in a SUV. Researched, test-drove (including renting SUVs for business trips) and compared models I deemed viable for a 2+week road trip. Finalists were the Lexus RX and Acura MDX. German brands, too expensive for purchase and service. Korean models, lacked heft. American durability remains questionable. Have owned both Lexus and Acura cars. Equally great quality and value. Dilemma time. Styling became deciding factor... couldn't overcome the ghastly front grill on the Lexus. With 600 miles now on the odometer, am pleased with everything on the MDX except thigh support in driver's seat. Technology package meets my expectations. Fun to drive. Confidence in the quality and value. No regrets in choosing the MDX.

reviews.title: Quick Review of the MDX Advance
reviews.review_text: Open pore natural wood accents, contrast stitching and piping on the seats, second row captains chairs, and power folding side mirrors combine to take the step up the MDX Advance's level of luxury. These features combined with a well-behaved 9-speed and the venerable and efficient V6 engine make for a drama-free ride. The 360-degree backup camera and parking sensors add a lot of confidence when backing in or out of a parking spot. These features are very helpful given the high hood and long wheelbase. On the downside, cargo capacity is small given the size of the vehicle. The high floor and low roof line limit the height of what can be placed in the back. There is a small enclosed area in the back floor but a large family should seek other more practical options. Overall it's a fantastic vehicle that provides a level of features and refinement that matches competitors' more expensive offerings. We're expecting it to serve as a reliable vehicle for many years.

reviews.title: Luxury for your money
reviews.review_text: I love my Acura MDX. I bought it gently used and have no regrets. The leather is soft, cushions comfortable for road trips, great space for luggage and kids. I love the three driving mode options. Sport for some quick get up, Comfort for a road trip and Normal for commuting. The display is large and easy to use. Speaker sound quality is impeccable. Gas mileage is unbelievable for a car of its size, I average 22-24 miles per gallon with everyday driving and as high as 26 miles per gallon on road trips. There are numerous seat settings allowing you to practically customize the drivers seat and you can adjust the steering wheel. The cost of regular maintenance like oil changes and tire rotations in the Seattle area is reasonable. The only design “flaw” that I struggle with are the center cup holders. One is larger than the other so sometimes the drinks in the larger cup holder wobble more causing some spillage. Also, because it has more gears than usual sometimes the automatic shifting takes a minute to get into a comfortable gear mainly on hills. It takes a minute to get used to the multiple gears. I have no major complaints. Great car for a single person looking for a fun, stylish, luxurious and reliable car. Also great for a small family with plenty of second row room for car seats and third row space for booster seats or kids without seating assistance.

reviews.review_text: Purchased certified used SH AWD 2016 MDX with 29K miles in 08/2019 for my wife. This is our first Acura and she absolutely loves it. The seats are extremely comfortable on trips, interior is quiet, back seat is roomy and there's plenty of room in the back for all our luggage. It has enough power to tackle hills and passing but don't expect muscle car acceleration. Contrary to some reviews I've seen, we like the auto transmission and it seems to almost always be in the right gear to maintain power. We'll definitely be keeping this one long term.

reviews.title: Bread crumb will disable your MDX
reviews.review_text: This is almost hard to believe - but.... we own an MDX with push button transmission controls. We hate it! Not only is the lack of a shift handle awkward, the push buttons allow any dust or crumbs to collect around the edges of the shift buttons. When a crumb makes its way to just the right (or wrong) place it will trick the computer into a state of idiot lice confusion and render the car unusable. In one instance we we’re driving on the interstate at 70mph when the car just went into neutral all by itself. We made it to the shoulder and had to be towed 180 miles. Do yourself a favor - and don’t by an Acura.

reviews.title: A/C Compressor
reviews.review_text: I really enjoyed this vehicle. Handled very well in all road conditions and was able to hold a significant amount of cargo. At 68000 miles the AC compressor failed. Surprising for such low mileage. Upon going to have repaired there was one used AC compressor in the entire country. All new units were on an indefinite backorder, meaning that the vehicle was dead in the water after a year-and-a-half of ownership. Speaking to the repair technician - he was not surprised at all. He informed me that he frequently services the AC units on Honda and Acura vehicles constantly due to poor design and corresponding reliability. The problem has been going on for years which means that the manufacturer has made no effort to fix the issue.

reviews.review_text: Ok for the price. There are better in this category, especially for when in come to $60,000. Look at Toyota Audi, Chevy and Cadillac. Acura isn't there yet.

reviews.title: Acrua MDX
reviews.review_text: Very fun car to drive very reliable a little pricey but well worth it. Handles like a dream comfortable seating decent gas mileage I highly recommended this vehicle

reviews.title: Most realiable car I own
reviews.review_text: Very economic on gas nice looking inside and out smoth driving and very spacious . Excellent vehicle for small family specially in you living on the East Coast because of the snow temporal

reviews.title: Great Car
reviews.review_text: The car handles very well yet is very comfortable. All of the controls are easy to use. The sound system is outstanding. There is more than ample room for passengers even in the third row. The gas mileage for a larger SUV is good. The car has power for acceleration when needed although the initial torque in the lowest gear could be higher. It would have been more convenient if the motor shut off when at a stop had a default of off and you could turn it on when you want rather than the current setting which requires turning it off anytime you don't wish to use it. It is a very comfortable car for long trips.

reviews.title: Awesome family hauler
reviews.review_text: The MDX is the first SUV in this household, we used to be a sedan and minivan family. This is like the best of both worlds. Great seating for the whole family, including the occasional friends, with the 3rd row and great cargo space, without being to large on the outside. It handles really nice, not quite like my BMW 3series, but great for such a large vehicle and has more then enough power. Love the 9 speed auto, the car is always in a great gear and responsive. The interior is all premium and very functional. Only downside is the radio and navigation system, it's not the most intuitive and doesn't have CarPlay, or Android Auto.

reviews.title: First Acura and I love it
reviews.review_text: This vehicle meets all my needs, with grandkids visiting us, the third row seat is a must. Interior is leather and put together well, solid vehicle

reviews.title: Moat fun car I have ever driven
reviews.review_text: I love this car! It fits my 6?3? body frame to a tee. With a 5 month old daughter it is the safest car and plenty of room for our family to grow. I love this car.

reviews.title: The only family car we both agreed on
reviews.review_text: We shopped for a long time for an SUV with a third row. My husband wanted something heavy duty and durable that was fun to drive and I wanted something pretty and comfortable, that was fun to drive. We both agree the MDX is the best vehicle for our family. It is so smooth and has all the bells and whistles (we have the advanced package), but also nothing like a mini-van.

reviews.title: Good solid car
reviews.review_text: Loved it, handles well..Comfortable and just an all around well built car. Not crazy about the shifter, but everything else is easy to use and accesible. 3rd row is for small people or kids

reviews.title: Best car i owned so far
reviews.review_text: Very good vehicle with all the necessary safety & reliability features in the right price range , has all the comfort and performance options as well

reviews.review_text: Seats are very comfortable and the drive is very smooth. Like my TL it?s got great pick up. As a golfer I especial like the stow away compartment, feels like a dresser for my shoes and golf attire.

reviews.title: 3rd MDX
reviews.review_text: This is my third MDX. Every time I look at other cars this still comes back as the best value for the money. It has a lot of bells & whistles & every year has more features than the last.

reviews.title: Happy car owner
reviews.review_text: Still learning about Acura MDX's controls and navigation systems. I expected better written documentation for seniors who are not as computer literate as our offspring. Learning by doing is painfully slow without adequate instruction. We love the car which is both comfortable and easy to drive but the instructions provided are below par for an octogenarian without formal computer skills.

reviews.title: New 2016 MDX Advanced package.
reviews.review_text: After leasing and 03 & 07 MDX we have return to Acura and are now leasing an 2016 MDX Advanced. This is the most technologically advanced SUV we have driven. I would recommend to the world how good this MDX handles and performs on the roads. Looking forward to happy miles with the MDX. I would recommend this MDX since it practically drives itself with interactive cruise control and lane departure option. Test drive one and you will see! I would like to give a shout out to Tempe Acura. Sales force and finance managers were gracious and easy to work with.

reviews.title: Pretty satisfied
reviews.review_text: My biggest complaint is the poor performance of the voice-activated commands, particularly as they relate to navigation commands. Very poor recognition when I try to use this feature. My 2nd complaint is Acura's failure to offer any covered maintenance such as oil and filter for at least the first two years, or 24,000 miles. I have purchased BMW, Lincoln, and even a Chevrolet Suburban that did provide this minimum level of covered service. The BMW is 4 years or 48,000 miles of full maintenance.

reviews.title: Poorest Suspension Experienced
reviews.review_text: Upon much research and recommendations from family friends, MDX owners, I purchased a 2016 MDX Sh-AWD. I was liking the experience until 4 days later on a trip the car kept going dead at interstate rest stops and hotel. After being jumped by the Acura service response number, we made it back and had the battery replaced. The rear suspension makes noise at sags or bumps on the roadway, like a gremlin hitting the under body with a rubber mallet. Have taken the car in many times, replaced rear struts, still noise. I was told until engineering finds an answer there is no answer. I am considering selling the car due to the unsolvable noise problem. I do like the car, the comfort and features, but I do not like the noise.

reviews.title: Elegant, Sporty and luxury
reviews.review_text: Open Road Acura of East Brunswick were very professional. Sales consultant Anthony Pinto provided my husband and I with great service, answered all our questions and made sure we were satisfied with the MDX. The finance manager was also very helpful and made sure we were satisfied with the deal. The service was over the top.

reviews.title: Great Buying Experience
reviews.review_text: The buying experience was great - Acura of Tempe sales consultant Chelsea and Finance Manager Virginia offered excellent customer service and a pleasurable buying experience. Very satisfied with the dealership and of course the MDX.

reviews.title: Acura MDX
reviews.review_text: Excellent car...few niggles...The in-car dashboard interface is horrendous. Difficult to understand and use. Navigation maps are antiquated (should learn something from Google on simplicity and accuracY0.

reviews.title: Bland styling but went with the safe choice
reviews.review_text: I had been shopping for 2-3 months for a mid to large AWD SUV that could seat 7 to 8 people. We loved our first MDX and owned it for 12 years and 180K miles, but we didn't jump on this 2016 MDX w/ tech and Entertainment because the styling seemed uninspiring both inside and out. Had to get entertainment/tech packages for 2nd row heated seats. Didn't want the DVD player or Lane assist stuff. The third row was cramped as well for two teenage kids. Surprisingly, all the full size SUVs didn't do much better in the third row either. Even the high end luxury brands. The GPS is clunky to operate. The voice activation doesn't really work. Even the sales person said Acura is working to improve it and showed me a faster, nonverbal way to work the bluetooth phone. I miss the days of simply pushing a real button to change heated seat settings or the radio station. The touch screen is distracting and visually cluttered. The UI on this has a long way to go. My $20K S. Korean made car has better tech and touch screen controls. Because of past experiences with Acura, I'm confident it'll run with few glitches. Simply change the oil, brake pads, tires and do scheduled maintenance. I worry the tech will fail before the mechanical stuff does. I view this car as a place holder until something better comes along. We like it. We just don't love it like our first MDX.

reviews.title: 4th Acura hard to beat for the price
reviews.review_text: Looked at this and the Lexus GX side by side in the end there was no comparison. The Acura MDX is above the grade in technology and inside interior. The push button 2nd row seats make it easy for any child to get in the 3rd row. I have had 2009 and 2011 MDX and the power difference and with sport suspension makes it seem so much faster in this new model. The handling of the MDX is so much better as well on the road. My wife is taking my MDX anytime she can.

reviews.title: Second MDX
reviews.review_text: We love our 2006 MDX so we decided to buy a 2016 MDX after looking at several alternatives. The new 9 speed transmission is very smooth and is giving us 18 mpg around town with all wheel drive. The technology is fantastic with lane keeping assist and cruse control that sets a distance from the car ahead and maintains that spacing in traffic. The CDs read into a hard drive so once they are played you no longer need to insert the CD. Lots of great features including safety features.

reviews.title: Most car for the investment I've owned.
reviews.review_text: This vehicle is the best I've owned for the following: 1. Smooth ride. 2. Safety features. 3. Exterior/interior appointments. 4. Overall design. 5. Technology.

reviews.title: Good Brand
reviews.review_text: The dealership and salesperson were great. The vehicle is nice, however, we found it a little small for our family. I like the Brand!

reviews.title: Lomg term performance
reviews.review_text: Still own a 2001 MDX with 256,000 basically care free miles. Could not resist purchase of a new MDX!!!! Its great and has all the modern technology.

reviews.title: 9 speed transmission is amazing!
reviews.review_text: The new 9 speed transmission that started in 2016 is the best thing that has happened to this already great suv. I read the previous review on here & was amazed on the response & lack of knowledge that they must have received from their salesperson. I drove a 2015 & the difference is night & day. Paddle shifting this suv is an amazing experience & adds to the already sporty feel. Far better than the BMW X5, Lincoln MKX, Audi q5 & q7, etc. Traded my Lexus RX for a 2016 MDX & feel like the quality of my mdx is more comparable to what Lexus used to offer. Great sales experience as well. Overall satisfied!

reviews.title: 2012 MDX blows this away
reviews.review_text: Previously owned a 2012 MDX which was the most amazing vehicle I ever owned. Super comfortable seats, excellent acceleration, sports car handling, not a single complaint about anything Fast forward to trading it in for the 2016 upon lease coming to an end, I do NOT like this vehicle one bit. Doesn't handle anywhere near how the 2012 handled. Tried all 3 suspension settings, and no dice. I'm not confident behind the wheel after 2 months Acceleration seems to have a "turbo lag" effect or the old 4-barrel V8 effect... step on the gas hard and it delays a good second or two until it takes off And many times I was already going 30 - 40mph and stepped on the gas hard, only to find the vehicle winding out in the current gear for a few seconds until it finally shifted into the next gear. I don't see why a vehicle like this has 9 gears Next, the seats. Total downgrade in quality of material from the 2012 MDX. And seats are lower to the ground, not giving an SUV feeling, but more of a regular car feeling. I've tried all kinds of seat adjustments and just can't find that comfort spot Next, the dashboard stuff is ridiculous. Heated seats is now a very distracting multi-step process via touch screen, as opposed to a convenient switch to the right of the seat for Low, Off, High. Ditto for controlling fan speed, A/C and heat, navigation, and so on and so on. In the day and age of distracted drivers, this thing is nothing but a big giant distraction Finally, the safety features are the most frustrating thing I ever experienced. I am CONSTANTLY being hit with distracting and annoying beeps and flashing warnings on the dashboard. When trying to pass someone, when backing out of a parking spot, and so on and so on. Not to mention the so-called blind spot enhancer on the drivers side mirror. It makes me dizzy everytime I look in the mirror and see 2 different views of what's behind me, one normal view and one magnifying glass view Bottom line... I would give ANYTHING to trade this thing in and step back to a 2012 MDX, and would not recommend the 2016 to anyone...

The ELS Surround Sound System is as good as anything out there (though I wish they still supported DVD-Audio, which I enjoy on my 2009 Acura TSX). The third row is small and only for children, but that suits us fine. We pulled the 3rd row down for now as it adds a good bit of storage.

Seats are comfortable after owning a Cadillac for years I was spoiled and no other SUV fit my needs. The only complaint would be V6 engine not V8 but power is enough and saves on fuel.

reviews.review_text: The car is "luxury" where it counts: drivability, comfort, fun. I already have a 2004 MDX, which is thoroughly battered enough that we keep it for transporting dogs and groceries. This newer 2015 is for fun: road trips, nights out, etc. It's been reengineered to become a true luxury SUV.

reviews.title: Perfect size, luxury pkg and value
reviews.review_text: I had a CRV and quickly outgrew it, as I need a lot of cargo space and a large enough back seat to fit at least one car seat plus two additional passengers. MDX has all the features I wanted and the cargo and passenger space that I need!

reviews.title: Test drive
reviews.review_text: I test drove this car a few times as I was looking to possibly purchase a used mid sized suv. The MDX had a decent car rating and i liked the third row seating. The only thing i did not care for is the two infotainment screens... one for navigation and the other for everything else... too busy.

reviews.title: Best car I have owned.
reviews.review_text: I love this car. I own the sh -AWD with Technology package. It does everything well. It is quiet and comfortable. I can be fast when you want it to be. If you want an suv that can tow 5000 lbs and seats 7 there is no competition.

reviews.title: Over all not bad. some chirping noise from engine
reviews.review_text: This is our second Acura. First was a 05 TL which had a great engine but the car was not quite. Rattles and squeaks as compared to my 03 camry which was so smooth. We've had it for just a week and i notice chirping sound from the engine. it is especially very noticeable at lower speed or when idle. Infotainment is very confusing. ride is smooth and quiet. We first thought about the Highlander but then my wife liked the way to mdx looked plus it has better cargo behind 3rd row. I think Acura's are just not as smooth and refined as lexus. Still no major complaints yet about this mdx. Can't give much updates yet on reliability on the mdx but our tl had minor electronics issues.

reviews.title: Great value for money
reviews.review_text: This car is indeed a great value for money. At the price point, this offers a great mix of performance, utility (optional 3rd row) and comfort. Being one of the few cars that hold their value so well in this category, I can see why people love MDX. Do watch out for the engine noise issue though. Apparently this doesn't give you a problem car, but you may want to walk away from the car when you hear it.

I have only owned this car for 1 month, but have had a previous Acura Integra for 10 years and Honda minivans for 12 years. Looking forward to another decade of Acura!

reviews.title: My second MDX
reviews.review_text: This will be my forth Acura and I've been extremely satisfied with all of them. I started it in the year 2000 with a 2001 Sport Coupe with the 6 cyl engine and kept it for 17 trouble free years, only repair being the transmission recall to change out the factory transmission. At the dealership suggestion I replaced motor mounts while the transmission recall was being exercised. Would have traded it in on this a new TSX but all they'd offer was $750 on the trade-in. I sold it myself for $3,000. I also owned a 2004 MDX that I'd bought used in 2008. It was my daily driver and I liked it a lot but after 6 years the transmission started to occasionally drop out of gear. So I traded that MDX in on a new 2013 TSX for my wife. She loves it. It's been trouble free for 3 years and I doubt if she'll ever let it go. It's the perfect size for smaller women. At that time I still had the 2001 coupe for my daily driver. I felt the loss without my MDX and suffered that loss for 3 years. Finally, I bought my current 2015 MDX, 2 years old and lightly used, and have had it now for 3 months. I'm dealing with a recent problem where the hatch seems to open on it's own accord. It's only recently has it done that. Last night my neighbor called saying my hatch was open. OK, I'm getting old and had not paid attention. That's the forth time in about a month it's done that and I hadn't opened the rear hatch for anything that day. I've swapped key fobs to see if the #1 Driver Fob was triggering the hatch inadvertently. I'm waiting to see if that's the solution. Otherwise, I'd have given my 2015 MDX as a five star award. I came to this web site to see if any other MDX owners were having the hatch problem.

reviews.title: 2015 Acura
reviews.review_text: Have been very impressed with the performance of this vehicle, from the multiple driving styles (Comfort,Normal, Sport) has noticeable changes in performance in each. The accessories make a nice addition to the appearance so we went with: running boards, fog lights, sports front grill. I changed from what I thought was a larger SUV and at first was thinking the interior size was less than we were accustomed but in reality the front 2 rows are more comfortable and offer just as much space. reviews.title: My first Honda/Acura vehicle and not my last
reviews.review_text: 2014 Acura MDX, Tech (FWD). White Diamond Pearl with Eucalyptus interior. My MDX is five model years old now and the odometer is currently at around 53k miles. In the past I've traded in Toyotas much sooner, after three years or approximately 40k miles, although I plan on keeping this great Acura a while longer. Aside from a computer issue which caused the engine to surge at certain speeds, which was covered for free by a service bulletin (plus a free loaner), there have been ZERO ISSUES with this vehicle, plus with my FWD I'm getting 17 city and 32-33 highway. The interior is a bit plain, but the imitation wood is tasteful and not nearly as gaudy as in the previous generation. Plus, this is an SUV after all, not a plush luxury barge of the 1980's. My entire family switched to Toyota from GM during the late 1990's due to plummeting GM quality, however due to similar issues with Toyota, we have begun moving into Honda and Acura vehicles for the better comfort and higher quality. I love my 2014 Acura MDX, and for an SUV I consider it to be very good looking.

reviews.title: One of the most comfortable car I've owned
reviews.review_text: I had an Acura TL previously. The seats hurt my back and made my hamstring tight, so even though it was so much fun to drive, I had to let it go. I was between the BMW X5 and this car. I test drove the BMW first. IT had a lot of great features, but less gas mileage and less seating room. Then I went to test drive the MDX. It has a very comfortable ride on comfort mode and I like that I could switch to Sport if desired, nice soft touch materials and technology package. So far, my MDX has been very reliable as it nears 100,000 miles. The only downside has been a weird fluttering noise on the drivers side. It is low pitch but is really noticeable. This sound coincide when you drive at high speeds (highway driving) and I notice it from the window. If I open and close the window a time or two it may disappear for a while. I asked the technicians to check it and they did not notice it. It is annoying when I can't get rid of it for the ride. Plenty of power when needed. Gas Mileage not ideal, but better than a lot of other SUVs in it's class. Overall, It is byfar the Best SUV in the market at its Category .

reviews.title: Great looking SUV... Until it becomes unreliable.

I was shocked to find out that Not only was it a $2,600 repair, but worse there or no new or used units available in the United States and the air conditioning unit was on backorder with no definite time of when they were going to receive any new units. So right now the car is dead and cannot operate and it cannot be repaired. I don't even know how something like this happens this is a terrible car company.
